_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The management and employees of GRAINCO FS, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Mazon Fire Department, Grundy County Emergency Management Agency or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



The primary activity at the facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop protection nutrient. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. The storage and handling system consists of storage tanks, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks. 



This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rules and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of the Compressed Gas Association's (CGA's) "American National Standard Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" (6th edition), commonly referred to "ANSI/CGA G-2.1 2014", as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health  Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program.



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:

-have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; not

-to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage or environmental damage.



This is a non-responding facility. The facility has:

-a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

-provided state and l

ocal authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).  In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Mazon Fire Department and Grundy County EMA and request that they respond to the emergency.  Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and EMA. 



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  In 2020, we plan to do extensive maintenance and upgrade the facility to meet new state regulations for the handling and storage of anhydrous ammonia.
